race.name: Wasatch All-Road
race.tagline: Northern Utah mountain gravel in Wasatch Range near Park City.

climate.description: High altitude with variable mountain conditions. Afternoon thunderstorms possible.

terrain.surface: Mountain gravel roads with significant elevation. High altitude terrain with challenging climbing.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional Utah mountain event. High altitude and significant climbing but regional field and infrastructure.

biased_opinion.summary: Wasatch All-Road offers a genuine mountain gravel challenge with high altitude and significant climbing in the beautiful Wasatch Range. Francis is a small town but proximity to Park City and Salt Lake City provides good access and amenities. The course is challenging with 6000 feet of climbing at 6000-8000+ feet elevation. It's a well-organized regional event with a moderate field.
strengths: Near Park City and Salt Lake City
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional Utah mountain gravel race with genuine altitude and climbing challenges. Worth it for Utah cyclists or those seeking a mountain gravel experience near Park City. Not a destination race for distant travelers, but a good regional mountain event.

final_verdict.one_liner: Regional Utah mountain gravel with high altitude and significant climbing in Wasatch Range.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in Utah or the Wasatch Front and want a mountain gravel challenge—yes, it's a well-organized event with genuine altitude and climbing. If you're traveling from far away—there are more prestigious mountain events elsewhere.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Utah mountain events: Crusher in the Tushar (if running), Leadville 100. For similar regional mountain vibes: other Wasatch events.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Francis has basic lodging. Park City (nearby) has resort options but is expensive.
logistics.food: Small town with basic dining. Park City has more options.

history.origin_story: Regional gravel event in Wasatch Range.

course_description.character: Mountain gravel with significant climbing at high altitude.
course_description.signature_challenge: 6000 feet of climbing at 6000-8000+ feet altitude in Wasatch Range.

non_negotiables.why: Racing at 6000-8000+ feet requires altitude acclimatization or preparation.
6000 feet of climbing requires strong aerobic capacity and climbing fitness.
Utah afternoon thunderstorms are dangerous. Know when to abandon and seek shelter.

marketplace_variables.race_hook: 62 miles of Wasatch Range mountain gravel at 6000-8000+ feet.
marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: Regional mountain event in Francis with 6000 feet of climbing.

logistics.explanation: Multiple distance categories from Mini Yeti to Bigfoot with BikeReg registration shows solid organization. Charlotte Backus noted adequate feed zone stocking: "definitely needed to stock up at the second feed zone for water," though she had to manage nutrition carefully. Utah Gravel Series delivers "the best volunteers in the biz" according to their reputation.

length.explanation: Charlotte Backus structured a week-long recovery protocol after Gravel Worlds including "8 hours each night" sleep, daily Theragun use, and carb loading "50-60 grams each day" starting Wednesday before the Saturday race. The distance demands serious preparation and recovery planning for competitive riders.

technicality.explanation: The Wasatch Wall features "chunky loose gravel and consistent areas of 9-14% inclines" with sections that are "not ridable." Charlotte Backus spent a year "working on skills and getting comfortable with the big rocks" coming from road background. Even riders with 2.4-inch tires report "fishtailing up some of the climbs." Similar technical demands to Gravel Worlds.

elevation.explanation: 10,560 feet of climbing in the Bigfoot category is serious vertical punishment - more than most riders can handle properly. 'The Wall' course feature suggests they've identified the perfect spot to separate pretenders from contenders. This is mountain suffering, not rolling hills with elevation marketing. More climbing than SBT GRVL at the same score. As Reddit user puts it: "I did the mini-yeti route this morning and found it rewarding but also incredibly difficult."

climate.explanation: August racing in Utah high country means hot valley starts with cooler mountain temperatures - pack layers or suffer the consequences. Heber City sits around 5,600 feet base elevation so you're already starting thin. Weather data is sparse but this is mountain desert climate - expect temperature swings and afternoon thunderstorm potential. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL.

altitude.explanation: Starting around 5,600 feet elevation with climbs reaching much higher into Wasatch range terrain. One rider noted "I've only been in Utah a few weeks, so elevation is not my friend" - the altitude differential hits non-acclimated riders immediately and compounds throughout the long climbing sections. Higher altitude racing, comparable to SBT GRVL.

adventure.explanation: Utah Wasatch range backcountry delivers wilderness gravel experience at 77% unpaved surfaces. The Bigfoot theming either enhances the mountain mystique or annoys you - depends on your folklore tolerance. Remote enough to feel adventurous without being dangerously isolated, though specific course routing details remain mysterious.

prestige.explanation: Part of the Utah Gravel Series but you won't find pro field depth or national recognition here. The Bigfoot/Sasquatch theming is cute but doesn't mask the reality - this is grassroots racing without the big names or media coverage. No prize money, no YouTube highlights, just another regional gravel event trying to build its reputation.

race_quality.explanation: Multiple distance options from Mini Yeti to Bigfoot (82-99.9 miles) show decent race organization. The Bigfoot category delivers 10,560 feet of climbing at 77% gravel - that's real suffering properly packaged. Course features 'the Wall' which suggests they understand how to break riders properly.

experience.explanation: Heber City location puts you in Utah high country terrain. The Bigfoot folklore angle is either charming or cheesy depending on your tolerance for theme races. 10,560 feet of climbing in the Bigfoot category means you'll earn your finisher photo, but don't expect frills beyond the basic gravel race experience.

community.explanation: Utah Gravel Series promotes a 'grassroots feel' and 'groads that smile back' - classic regional series marketing speak. Limited online chatter or race reports suggest a smaller, local community rather than destination event status. The multi-category format indicates they're trying to build participation across ability levels. As Event Quality puts it: "As the Utah Gravel Series has become known to have the best volunteers in the biz as well as an after party full of food, beverages, and extraordinary prizes, you'll be sure to enjoy yourself in that ..."

field_depth.explanation: With a field of 100-300 riders, regional Utah event without visible pro participation or competitive depth. No race results, winner announcements, or field size data suggests modest participation numbers. This is weekend warrior territory, not where you go to test yourself against serious competition. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100. As Reddit user puts it: "This race was absolutely brutal, especially with the 12 miles of climbing at the beginning and all of the rock fields thought out this course."

value.explanation: Multiple distance options allow riders to choose their challenge level, from Mini Yeti up to the full Bigfoot category. Post-race festivities include "food, beverages, and extraordinary prizes" as part of the Utah Gravel Series reputation, delivering solid event value for regional pricing.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $80-120. Equipment demands include wider tires - even S-Works Pathfinder Pros "slipped a few times" on 17% grades while 2.4-inch tires still caused fishtailing. Heber City/Francis location accessible from Salt Lake City area without resort-level accommodation costs affecting overall race weekend budget. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

citations.label: reddit.com: Did My First Ever Gravel Race Yesterday Wasatch

primary.name: IRC Boken Double Cross
primary.why: Underrated mixed-terrain tire. Fast center with confident shoulder grip.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

videos.title: Can You Use A Gravel Bike As A Road Bike?
videos.description:
Once you've changed out tyres, how much difference really is there between a modern gravel and road bike? We find out.

Cade Media Podcast: https://podfollow.com/the-wild-ones/view

SUPPORT Francis Cade and Cade Media directly:
Via Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/franciscade
Via our clothing brand WILD: https://wearethewildones.co.uk/collections/

videos.title: Case of the Mondays - a Utah Gravel Ride
videos.description: Monday evening ride over Bountiful Peak, up to Francis Peak, and back. Steep climbs, incredible views, and rugged gravel descents.

videos.title: All-Road Exploration : Flagstaff to Grand Canyon
videos.description:
To put our latest creation to the test, we asked the State Bicycle Co. team to saddle up and push the new 6061 All-Road bikes to the limit, riding trails and dirt roads from Flagstaff to the Grand Canyon via the Arizona Trail. The rocky-route, most appropriate for hikers and mountain bikes, provided a perfect way to see how capable and these machines could be.

Learn more about the ride here: https://www.statebicycle.com/blogs/news/all-road-exploration-flagstaff-to-grand-canyon-on-the-6061-black-label-all-road

Check out the bikes here: https://www.statebicycle.com/blogs/news/first-look-state-bicycle-co-6061-all-road

Music: 'Good Time' by JW Francis : http://www.sundaybest.net/release/good-time/

terrain_notes.text: UK gravel is typically a mix of walking tracks, bridal ways, mountain bike trails, and toe path style packed down gravel paths that aren't used by cars. It's more technical than smooth gravel tracks with new challenges around every corner.
Surfaces can vary from hard packed gravel like toe paths by rivers to muddy walking style tracks. Sometimes it's paths, sometimes trails, sometimes muddy, sometimes not - it's always muddy in the UK.

gear_mentions.text: For hard packed gravel like toe paths or gravel roads, slick tires might still be the best choice. The gravel World Champs in Kansas was won on 34mm slicks with no real tread.
The wider you go the more comfortable ride you can have because you can lower the pressure without risk of pinch punctures.
For muddy walking style tracks you'll need knobblies. Closer together and smaller knobs are faster rolling but have less grip. Bigger and more spread out knobs give more grip but are slower rolling.
If you want to use a gravel bike on the road, changing to a set of road tires will make a massive difference. Road tires are faster due to lower rolling resistance and better aerodynamics.

race_day_tips.text: Work out what surfaces you're going to be riding before you choose your tires. Tire choice can make or break your ride depending on conditions like mud, grass, hard pack gravel, or rocks.
If you sign up to an event advertised as gravel, it might be more technical than just a smooth gravel track. Get off and walk if you need to, trust your equipment and enjoy yourself.

rider_intel.search_text: Riders describe gravel cycling as a broad term meaning riding off-road, with UK conditions typically involving walking tracks, bridal ways, mountain bike trails, and packed gravel paths. Terrain varies from hard-packed gravel suitable for slick tires to muddy tracks requiring knobby tires. Tire choice is crucial - slick tires work for hard surfaces and the gravel World Champs was won on 34mm slicks, while muddy conditions need knobblies with bigger, spread-out knobs for grip despite slower rolling. Modern gravel bikes are highly capable, more so than 1990s mountain bikes according to experienced riders. The key is matching tire choice to expected surface conditions, as this can make or break the ride experience. Events may be more technical than expected, so riders should be prepared to walk sections if needed.
